Article Title: Super Bowl 59 Ticket Prices Are 17% Cheaper Than Last Year’s; Find Out Why
Article Text:
The stage is set for this year’s Super Bowl. Source: Getty

From Size Of The Venue to Fan Fatigue, A Few Key Factors Decide Super Bowl Ticket Prices

Super Bowl 59 may very well be one of the most talked-about and heavily publicised Super Bowls in NFL history. Not only is the Kansas City Chiefs aiming for a rare three-peat, but the team’s tight end Travis Kelce is in a relationship with the most popular pop star of her generation, Taylor Swift. However, ticket prices this year for Super Bowl LIX are down significantly ahead of Sunday's game.StubHub reported this week that the "Get In" price was $3,229 which is 5 per cent lower than the previous day and down 43 per cent compared to this time last year. However, StubHub spokesperson Adam Budelli recently broke down why there are a few practical reasons for this.According to reports, more than 4,700 tickets are available on StubHub on Wednesday night. The average ticket price has reportedly dropped to about $6,900, which marks a 17% drop from last year. However, Budelli explains that this is not unnatural since the price drop depends upon the Caesars Superdome’s ability to accommodate over 15,000 more fans, the availability of hotel rooms, and to some extent, fan fatigue.There are 74,295 seats and six levels in the Caesars Superdome. However, the two suite levels at the Superdome are privately owned and hence exclusive. 7 per cent of all tickets sold have been buyers from Kansas or Missouri, which is surprising since this is a big game for the Kansas City Chiefs.But Budelli shares, “They’ve seen their team win. It’s hard to justify spending $10,000, year after year, if you’ve already seen it.” Budelli told AP that some tickets are still available, but they are being sold quickly.Also Read: What is Super Bowl and why is everyone googling it? “Compared to last year, which was the most expensive Super Bowl in history on StubHub, that’s actually down 56%, making this Super Bowl much more approachable — I don’t want to say affordable — when compared to last year,” Budelli said.As per Ticketmaster, historically, the average resale ticket to the Super Bowl has ranged between $4,000 and $6,000; the platform has also pointed out that the ticket price “fluctuates drastically” based on the game's location, the lineup, seat location, and date of purchase.Budelli also pointed out that the venue for last year’s Super Bowl was a big reason for the inflated prices of its tickets. Last year, the game was held in Las Vegas and the three-hour game was turned into a week full of festivities for attending fans which hiked up the prices. Budelli shared that this year’s ticket prices are more in line with the 2023 rates.We’ve seen a 14% increase in ticket purchases from Kansas City Chiefs fans. Now, the gap is around 15% from Pennsylvania and about 9% from Kansas and Missouri. While it still favours the Eagles, the numbers may improve for Chiefs fans as the weekend progresses," he added.Typically Super Bowl tickets get cheaper from two weeks out, reaching their lowest price on game day. In 2024, Gametime's cheapest Super Bowl ticket declined from $9,400 two weeks out to $7,100 the day of the game, which marks a 24% drop.
Article Summary: StubHub reported this week that the "Get In" price was $3,229 which is 5 per cent lower than the previous day and down 43 per cent compared to this time last year. StubHub spokesperson Adam Budelli recently broke down why there are a few practical reasons for this.

Article Title: Jon Batiste: Who is Jon Batiste? Everything to know about Super Bowl 59 anthem singer's songs, lyrics & more
Article Text:
Courtesy of David Needleman

Jon Batiste’s Musical Journey: From Street Performances to Grammy Wins



Super Bowl LIX: What to Expect



If there’s one thing we can all agree on, it’s that the Super Bowl isn’t just about football—it’s about the spectacle, the halftime show, and of course, that iconic national anthem moment. And this year, none other than the multi-talented Jon Batiste will be delivering the “Star-Spangled Banner” before the big game kicks off.Born into the legendary Batiste family in Metairie, Louisiana, Jon Batiste has been breathing music since day one. He started on drums, but by 11, the piano had stolen his heart. He trained at the New Orleans Center for Creative Arts and later polished his skills at Juilliard in New York. From street performances (he calls them "love riots") to global tours, this man has lived and breathed music across more than 40 countries.If you don't know Batiste from his viral street performances, you probably recognize him as the former bandleader on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert. But that's just one piece of his insane career. Now let's talk about the hardware: an Academy Award for his work on Disney/Pixar's Soul , a Golden Globe, a BAFTA, a Critics' Choice Award, and oh, just five Grammy wins in one night for his album WE ARE—including Album of the Year in 2022!Batiste's musical fingerprints are everywhere. He's worked with Stevie Wonder, Prince, Willie Nelson, Lenny Kravitz, and Ed Sheeran—to name a few. He's also the Creative Director of the National Jazz Museum in Harlem and the Music Director for The Atlantic. Basically, if it involves music and culture, Batiste has probably had a hand in it.Batiste isn’t just singing the national anthem; he’s bringing soul, jazz, and a whole lot of energy to the Super Bowl stage. Expect a rendition that’s powerful, heartfelt, and uniquely Batiste. If his past performances are anything to go by, we might even see a surprise twist or two.So as the players prepare for a battle of glory in the Super Bowl, Jon Batiste is going to be the one that sets the tone for this upcoming legendary performance. Whether this is your game or you're just here for the music, one thing is for sure—the moment when Batiste comes on will not soon be forgotten.Also read - “She’s a Trump Fan!” – Donald Trump Predicts Chiefs Will Win Super Bowl, Praises Patrick Mahomes’ Wife
Article Summary: Jon Batiste will be singing the national anthem at the Super Bowl. He's worked with Stevie Wonder, Prince, Willie Nelson, Lenny Kravitz, and Ed Sheeran. Batiste is also the Creative Director of the National Jazz Museum in Harlem.

Super Bowl Overtime: How It Works

The New Overtime Rule And How To Play It

1. Duration of Overtime Periods

Each overtime period lasts 15 minutes, unlike the regular season, where overtime is capped at 10 minutes. This extended period ensures there’s enough time to determine a clear winner.

If the score remains tied after the first 15-minute period—or if the team that received the second possession hasn’t completed its initial drive—another overtime period begins. This process continues until a winner is declared.

2. Guaranteed Possession for Both Teams

One of the most significant differences from the regular season is that both teams are guaranteed a chance to possess the ball at least once in overtime. This rule was introduced prior to the 2022 season to address concerns about fairness.

In the regular season, if the team that receives the opening kickoff scores a touchdown, the game ends immediately. However, in the playoffs, even if the first team scores a touchdown, the opposing team still gets a chance to respond. This ensures a more balanced competition.

6. Coin Toss and Captain’s Choice

Key Takeaways for Fans

Overtime periods are 15 minutes long, and multiple periods are played if necessary.

The Super Bowl has been around since 1967, yet only two editions have needed overtime to crown a champion. The first came in 2017 when the Patriots miraculously erased a 28-3 deficit against the Falcons, with Tom Brady leading New England to victory. The second occurred in 2024 when the Chiefs and 49ers battled into extra time, with Kansas City prevailing. Could history repeat itself? If another Super Bowl heads to OT, here’s what you need to know about the rules.The NFL’s overtime rules have always been a hot topic, especially in the playoffs, where games cannot end in a tie. While the format remains largely the same in the regular season and postseason, there are crucial distinctions in playoff overtime—especially after the rule changes introduced in 2022. These adjustments were implemented in response to intense matchups like the unforgettable Chiefs vs. Bills 2022 AFC Divisional Round, where Kansas City secured the win with a touchdown on their first overtime possession, leaving Buffalo without a chance to respond.In the NFL postseason, including the Super Bowl, overtime is designed to guarantee both teams a fair shot at victory while maintaining the intensity of the game. Here’s a breakdown of the key rules:"Both teams must have the opportunity to possess the ball at least once during the extra period, unless the team kicking off to start the overtime period scores a safety on the receiving team’s initial possession, in which case the team that kicked off is the winner." – NFL RulebookThe only exception is if the team that begins with the ball commits a safety. In this rare scenario, the game ends, and the kicking team is declared the winner, just as in the regular season.If the first team to possess the ball doesn’t score, or if the score is tied after both teams have had a possession, the game continues, and the next score—by any method (touchdown, field goal, or safety)—wins.Importantly, if a team scores a touchdown to win the game, extra points are not attempted, as the game ends immediately upon the score.Each team is allotted three timeouts per half (with two overtime periods counting as a half). This allows for strategic clock management during the extended play.There are no coach’s challenges in overtime. All replays are initiated by the replay official, ensuring that critical calls are reviewed without disrupting the flow of the game.If the score is still tied after the first overtime period—or if the second team’s initial possession hasn’t concluded—another 15-minute period begins. There’s a two-minute intermission between overtime periods, but no halftime break after the second period.If the game remains unresolved after four overtime periods, a new coin toss takes place, and play continues until a winner emerges. The NFL is committed to playing as many overtime periods as necessary to determine a victor."If there is still no winner at the end of a fourth overtime period, there will be another coin toss, and play will continue until a winner is declared." – NFL RulebookOvertime begins with a coin toss, and the winning team can choose to kick, receive, defer, or select which goal to defend.If the game goes into a second overtime period, the captain who lost the first coin toss gets to make the choice—unless the team that won the toss deferred their decision initially.For NFL fans, understanding the postseason overtime rules is crucial, especially during the high-pressure moments of the playoffs. Article Text:

A "Brady" family ring (not Tom Brady’s personal ring) from Super Bowl LI brought in $344,927 in 2018.

How many Super Bowl rings are produced each year?

Notable Super Bowl rings that made headlines for their designs

Their rings celebrated the “Philly Special” trick play, with 127 diamonds symbolizing the jersey numbers of Nick Foles (9), Corey Clement (30), and Trey Burton (88). After their legendary 28-3 comeback against the Atlanta Falcons, their rings featured 283 diamonds. Subtle, right? Miami Dolphins (1972): The Dolphins commemorated their perfect season with 17 diamonds, representing each victory that year.

Coaches with the most Super Bowl wins

Read More:

Super Bowl rings aren’t just jewelry. They’re the ultimate flex in the NFL, a shiny reward for months of bruises, broken bones, and mind-numbing drills. Designed with diamonds, gold, and symbolism, these rings are status icons, bragging rights, and history all in one.Let’s take it back to January 15, 1967. The Green Bay Packers crushed the Kansas City Chiefs to win the very first Super Bowl. Their reward? A ring designed by Packers coach Vince Lombardi with Jostens. It had a clean, simple look—just a half-carat diamond in white gold. No over-the-top designs or endless bling like today.And that’s where it all began.But rings in sports weren’t new. Back in 1922, the New York Giants baseball team started the trend by choosing rings over traditional awards like pocket watches. The NFL eventually hopped on board after that first Super Bowl.These rings scream opulence. Yellow or rose gold? Check. Diamonds everywhere? Double check.Here’s the catch, though: every ring is different. The Los Angeles Rams put 20 carats of diamonds on their 2022 rings—a record. Some teams go all out with hundreds of tiny diamonds, while others go with larger stones.Mandatory features include:In 2010, the Green Bay Packers even ditched gold and used platinum for their rings.One thing’s for sure—the designs only get flashier every year.Believe it or not, the losing Super Bowl team also gets rings. No, they’re not as glitzy as the winner’s rings, but it’s still a ring. It honors their conference championship win (either AFC or NFC). Pity ring? Maybe. But you won’t see them throwing theirs away.Let’s talk money. A single ring costs between $30,000 and $50,000 to make. Yeah,Teams usually spend millions to cover everyone—players, coaches, staff, sometimes even the janitors. The NFL pitches in $5,000 per ring for the first 150 rings. But when you’re putting 14.8-carat diamonds on these things like the 2024 winners did, $5,000 doesn’t stretch far.Teams decide if they’ll pay the remaining costs or dock players' salaries. In 2023, Kansas City Chiefs players shelled out $11,000 each for their Super Bowl rings. But hey, that $157,000 Super Bowl bonus probably softened the blow.No one’s close to touching Tom Brady’s record. He owns seven Super Bowl rings—six with the New England Patriots and one with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. His partnership with coach Bill Belichick wasdynasty of the 2000s and 2010s.The only player somewhat near his orbit? Charles Haley, who won five Super Bowl rings with the San Francisco 49ers and the Dallas Cowboys.For context, the Pittsburgh Steelers’ entire legendary ‘70s roster—Terry Bradshaw, Franco Harris, Joe Greene, Lynn Swann, and others—each has four rings. Brady’s on a whole different level.Both teams have six Super Bowl victories. The Patriots’ dominance came under Bill Belichick and Tom Brady. The Steelers? They built a dynasty in the ‘70s under Chuck Noll, winning four titles in that decade alone.If you ever find a Super Bowl ring lying around (good luck with that), hold onto it—it’s a goldmine.Super Bowl rings are collector’s items, and some fans will drop millions to own a piece of NFL history.It depends on the team’s priorities. On average, 300 to 900 rings are made annually. The NFL provides funding for 150 rings, but teams often make extra for inactive players, support staff, and sometimes family members. The whole process—design to production—takes about four months.Some rings come with stories that live on in football folklore:Bill Belichick leads the pack with six rings as head coach of the New England Patriots.Chuck Noll won four with the Pittsburgh Steelers, while Bill Walsh and Joe Gibbs each have three. Andy Reid, coaching for the Kansas City Chiefs, now has three rings and is making a case for his spot among the all-time greats.
Article Summary: Super Bowl rings are the ultimate flex in the NFL, a shiny reward for months of bruises, broken bones, and mind-numbing drills. Designed with diamonds, gold, and symbolism, these rings are status icons, bragging rights, and history all in one. The Los Angeles Rams put 20 carats of diamonds on their 2022 rings.
